title: FinReport: Explainable Stock Earnings Forecasting via News Factor Analyzing Model
abstract: The paper introduces FinReport, an automatic system designed to assist ordinary investors in stock earnings forecasting by analyzing financial news and generating comprehensive reports. Unlike traditional methods that require financial expertise, FinReport integrates three modules: news factorization, return forecasting, and risk assessment. The news factorization module combines semantic understanding with stock factors, the return forecasting module evaluates news impact on market sentiment, and the risk assessment module controls investment risk using historical data. Experiments on real-world datasets validate the system's effectiveness and explainability, offering a user-friendly solution for non-expert investors.

title: Fine-Tuning Large Language Models for Stock Return Prediction Using Newsflow
abstract: This paper explores the application of fine-tuned large language models (LLMs) for stock return forecasting using financial newsflow. The study compares encoder-only (DeBERTa) and decoder-only (Mistral, Llama) LLMs to analyze their distinct text representation methods and their impact on forecasting performance. Two integration techniques for token-level representationsâbottleneck and aggregated representationsâare evaluated. Experiments on real financial news and investment universes demonstrate that aggregated representations generally enhance portfolio performance, with decoder LLMs excelling in larger universes and Mistral showing robust performance across different settings. The findings highlight that LLM-derived return predictions outperform conventional sentiment scores in portfolio construction.

title: Transformer for Times Series: an Application to the S&P500
abstract: This paper explores the application of transformer models to financial time series, focusing on both synthetic data generated from an Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process and real S&P500 data. The study details the construction of datasets, the proposed transformer architecture, and presents encouraging results. For synthetic data, the model accurately predicts the next move, while for the S&P500, it provides insights into quadratic variation and volatility prediction. The findings suggest that transformers can be effectively adapted for financial time series analysis.

title: When AI Meets Finance (StockAgent): Large Language Model-based Stock Trading in Simulated Real-world Environments
abstract: This paper introduces StockAgent, a multi-agent AI system driven by large language models (LLMs) to simulate investor trading behaviors in real-world stock market environments. The system evaluates the impact of external factors such as macroeconomics, policy changes, and global events on trading activities. StockAgent addresses the test set leakage issue in existing AI-based trading simulations by preventing prior knowledge exploitation. The framework is tested with different LLMs in a realistic trading environment, demonstrating the influence of key external factors on trading behavior and stock price fluctuations. The research provides insights into LLM-based investment advice and stock recommendations, with the code available for public use.

title: FinRL-DeepSeek: LLM-Infused Risk-Sensitive Reinforcement Learning for Trading Agents
abstract: This paper introduces a novel risk-sensitive trading agent that combines reinforcement learning (RL) with large language models (LLMs). The approach extends the Conditional Value-at-Risk Proximal Policy Optimization (CPPO) algorithm by incorporating risk assessment and trading recommendation signals generated by LLMs from financial news. The method is backtested on the Nasdaq-100 index using financial news data from the FNSPID dataset and LLMs such as DeepSeek V3, Qwen 2.5, and Llama 3.3. The results demonstrate the potential of LLMs for feature extraction beyond standard sentiment analysis, with carefully designed prompts for stock recommendations and risk assessment. The code, data, and trading agents are publicly available.

title: XLSTM-MIXER: MULTIVARIATE TIME SERIES FORECASTING BY MIXING VIA SCALAR MEMORIES
abstract: The paper introduces xLSTM-Mixer, a novel model for multivariate time series forecasting that integrates temporal sequences, joint time-variate information, and multiple perspectives to produce robust predictions. The model begins with a linear forecast shared across variates, refined by xLSTM blocks to capture complex dynamics. It reconciles two distinct views to generate the final forecast. Extensive evaluations demonstrate its superior long-term forecasting performance compared to state-of-the-art methods, with thorough analysis confirming its robustness and effectiveness. This work contributes to the resurgence of recurrent models in time series forecasting.

title: Deep Learning in Characteristics-Sorted Factor Models
abstract: This article introduces an augmented deep factor model that generates latent factors for cross-sectional asset pricing. The model generalizes the conventional security sorting on firm characteristics by using a structural deep-learning framework to fit cross-sectional returns through generating risk factors. The model's economic-guided objective function minimizes aggregated realized pricing errors. Empirical results demonstrate robust asset pricing performance and strong investment improvements by identifying important raw characteristic sources. The approach provides a systematic way to automate the security-sorting process using deep-learning terminologies, offering a transparent 'white box' architecture that complements traditional methods.

title: A Hierarchical conv-LSTM and LLM Integrated Model for Holistic Stock Forecasting
abstract: The financial domain presents a complex environment for stock market prediction, characterized by volatile patterns and the influence of multifaceted data sources. Traditional models have leveraged either Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) for spatial feature extraction or Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) networks for capturing temporal dependencies, with limited integration of external textual data. This paper proposes a novel Two-Level Conv-LSTM Neural Network integrated with a Large Language Model (LLM) for comprehensive stock advising. The model harnesses the strengths of Conv-LSTM for analyzing time-series data and LLM for processing and understanding textual information from financial news, social media, and reports. In the first level, convolutional layers are employed to identify local patterns in historical stock prices and technical indicators, followed by LSTM layers to capture the temporal dynamics. The second level integrates the output with an LLM that analyzes sentiment and contextual information from textual data, providing a holistic view of market conditions. The combined approach aims to improve prediction accuracy and provide contextually rich stock advising.

title: LLM-Based Routing in Mixture of Experts: A Novel Framework for Trading
abstract: Recent advances in deep learning and large language models (LLMs) have facilitated the deployment of the mixture-of-experts (MoE) mechanism in the stock investment domain. However, traditional MoE models often rely on unimodal data and static neural network-based routers, leading to suboptimal expert selection. To address these limitations, we propose LLMoE, a novel framework that employs LLMs as the router within the MoE architecture. By leveraging LLMs' extensive world knowledge and reasoning capabilities, LLMoE integrates historical price data and stock news for more effective and interpretable expert selection. Experiments on real-world stock datasets demonstrate that LLMoE outperforms state-of-the-art MoE models and other deep learning approaches, while its flexible architecture allows for easy adaptation to various downstream tasks.

title: Learning Multiple Stock Trading Patterns with Temporal Routing Adaptor and Optimal Transport
abstract: This paper introduces the Temporal Routing Adaptor (TRA), a novel architecture designed to enhance stock prediction models by capturing multiple trading patterns in the stock market. TRA consists of independent predictors for different patterns and a router to assign samples to these predictors. The challenge of training without explicit pattern identifiers is addressed using an Optimal Transport (OT)-based learning algorithm, which optimizes sample-to-predictor assignments. Experiments on real-world stock ranking tasks demonstrate TRA's effectiveness, improving information coefficients (IC) over state-of-the-art baselines like Attention LSTM and Transformer.

title: KAN: KolmogorovâArnold Networks
abstract: Inspired by the Kolmogorov-Arnold representation theorem, we propose Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks (KANs) as promising alternatives to Multi-Layer Perceptrons (MLPs). Unlike MLPs with fixed activation functions on nodes, KANs feature learnable activation functions on edges, replacing linear weights with univariate spline functions. KANs demonstrate superior accuracy and interpretability, achieving comparable or better performance with smaller architectures in data fitting and PDE solving. They exhibit faster neural scaling laws and can be intuitively visualized, making them useful for scientific discovery in mathematics and physics. KANs combine the strengths of splines and MLPs, mitigating their respective weaknesses, and offer a new foundation for improving deep learning models.

It traces the evolution from traditional statistical models to deep learning, which enables scalable modeling across the investment pipeline. The paper highlights the emerging potential of large language models (LLMs) to extend AI beyond prediction, empowering autonomous agents to process unstructured data, generate alphas, and support self-iterative workflows. title: PATHFORMER: MULTI-SCALE TRANSFORMERS WITH ADAPTIVE PATHWAYS FOR TIME SERIES FORECASTING
abstract: The paper introduces Pathformer, a multi-scale Transformer with adaptive pathways designed for time series forecasting. Pathformer integrates temporal resolution and temporal distance for multi-scale modeling, dividing time series into patches of various sizes to capture different temporal characteristics. It employs dual attention to model both global correlations and local details. Adaptive pathways dynamically adjust the multi-scale modeling process based on input data's temporal dynamics, enhancing accuracy and generalization. Extensive experiments on eleven real-world datasets show Pathformer achieves state-of-the-art performance and exhibits strong generalization in transfer scenarios.

title: Large Language Models Are Zero-Shot Time Series Forecasters
abstract: This paper demonstrates that large language models (LLMs) like GPT-3 and LLaMA-2 can effectively perform zero-shot time series forecasting by encoding time series as strings of numerical digits and treating forecasting as next-token prediction. The proposed method, LLMTIME, tokenizes time series data and converts discrete token distributions into continuous densities, enabling LLMs to match or exceed the performance of specialized time series models without fine-tuning. Key advantages include handling missing data without imputation, incorporating textual side information, and explaining predictions. The study also explores how LLMs' biases for simplicity and repetition align with time series patterns like seasonality, and notes that performance generally scales with model size, though alignment interventions like RLHF can degrade calibration.

title: FlowHFT: Imitation Learning via Flow Matching Policy for Optimal High-Frequency Trading under Diverse Market Conditions
abstract: High-frequency trading (HFT) requires rapid adaptation to dynamic and volatile market conditions, which traditional models struggle with due to their reliance on historical data and restrictive assumptions. This paper introduces FlowHFT, a novel imitation learning framework based on flow matching policy, designed to learn and integrate strategies from multiple expert models, each proficient in specific market scenarios. FlowHFT adaptively adjusts investment decisions according to prevailing conditions and incorporates a grid-search fine-tuning mechanism to refine strategies for superior performance. Evaluated across diverse market environments, FlowHFT outperforms individual expert strategies, demonstrating robustness to sudden price jumps and achieving optimal performance in complex conditions. This study marks the first successful application of flow matching policy in stochastic market environments.

title: PEN: Prediction-Explanation Network to Forecast Stock Price Movement with Better Explainability
abstract: The paper introduces the Prediction-Explanation Network (PEN), a novel framework designed to predict stock price movements with enhanced explainability by jointly modeling text streams (e.g., financial news, social media posts) and price streams. PEN employs a shared representation learning module to identify texts associated with stock price movements, using a salient vector to characterize their correlation. This approach not only improves prediction accuracy by filtering irrelevant texts but also provides explanations for the predicted movements by highlighting crucial texts. Experimental results on real-world datasets show that PEN outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in accuracy and significantly enhances explainability compared to traditional attention mechanisms.

title: Reinforcement Learning with Maskable Stock Representation for Portfolio Management in Customizable Stock Pools
abstract: Portfolio management (PM) is a fundamental financial trading task that involves optimal periodic reallocation of capital among different stocks to maximize long-term profits. Reinforcement learning (RL) has shown promise in training profitable agents for PM, but existing methods focus on fixed stock pools, which do not align with investors' practical needs for customizable stock pools (CSPs). To address this, we propose EarnMore, an RL framework with maskable stock representation that handles PM with CSPs through one-shot training in a global stock pool (GSP). Key innovations include a masking mechanism for stocks outside the target pool, self-supervised learning for stock representations, and a re-weighting mechanism to focus on favorable stocks. Experiments on 8 subset stock pools from the US market demonstrate EarnMore's superiority over 14 baselines, with over 40% profit improvement.

title: Multi-modal Time Series Analysis: A Tutorial and Survey
abstract: Multi-modal time series analysis has emerged as a prominent research area in data mining, driven by the increasing availability of diverse data modalities such as text, images, and structured tabular data. However, challenges like data heterogeneity, modality gap, misalignment, and noise hinder effective analysis. Recent advancements leverage deep learning for cross-modal interactions, enhancing downstream tasks. This tutorial and survey provides a systematic overview of multi-modal time series datasets and methods, categorizing them via a unified framework of fusion, alignment, and transference at input, intermediate, and output levels. It also discusses real-world applications and future research directions.

title: Minute-by-Minute: Financial Marketsâ Reaction to the 2020 U.S. Election
abstract: This study examines the immediate impact of the 2020 U.S. presidential election on financial markets using minutely data from prediction markets. The authors analyze the relationship between the election outcome probabilities and various financial indicators, including currency pairs, bond prices, stock index futures, and market volatility. The findings reveal strong correlations consistent with 'risk-on' behavior as election results became clearer. The market reaction is decomposed into components related to reduced uncertainty and the probability of a Democratic presidency. Additionally, the study highlights differing market reactions to the presidential and Senate elections, with bond prices being particularly sensitive to the prospect of a combined Democratic Senate and Presidency.

title: A Survey of Large Language Models in Finance (FinLLMs)
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) have demonstrated significant capabilities in Natural Language Processing (NLP) tasks, attracting attention across various domains, including finance. Despite extensive research on general-domain LLMs, Financial LLM (FinLLM) research remains limited. This survey offers a comprehensive overview of FinLLMs, covering their history, techniques, performance, and challenges. It presents a chronological evolution from general-domain Pretrained Language Models (PLMs) to current FinLLMs, compares techniques used in financial PLMs and FinLLMs, summarizes performance evaluations on benchmark tasks, and discusses advanced financial NLP tasks. The paper also highlights opportunities and challenges such as hallucination, privacy, and efficiency, and provides a collection of datasets and benchmarks on GitHub.

title: FinDKG: Dynamic Knowledge Graphs with Large Language Models for Detecting Global Trends in Financial Markets
abstract: Dynamic knowledge graphs (DKGs) are effective structures for representing connections between objects over time and extracting information from unstructured data like financial news. This paper introduces a novel open-source fine-tuned large language model (LLM), the Integrated Contextual Knowledge Graph Generator (ICKG), designed to generate DKGs from financial news articles. The resulting DKG, FinDKG, is analyzed using an attention-based GNN architecture called KGTransformer. The model demonstrates superior performance in link prediction tasks and thematic investing, outperforming existing thematic ETFs. The contributions include the KGTransformer architecture, the ICKG LLM, and the open-source FinDKG dataset.

abstract: This paper addresses the challenge of identifying meaningful relationships between financial assets by proposing a neural model for training stock embeddings. Inspired by natural language processing techniques, the model leverages historical returns data to capture nuanced relationships between assets. The approach is detailed, and its utility is demonstrated through evaluations in real-world financial analytics tasks, outperforming traditional benchmarks. The paper highlights applications in portfolio optimization, diversification, and hedging, showcasing the potential of learned embeddings to enhance financial decision-making.

title: AutoTimes: Autoregressive Time Series Forecasters via Large Language Models
abstract: The paper proposes AutoTimes, a method to repurpose large language models (LLMs) as autoregressive time series forecasters without updating their parameters. By aligning the sequential structure of time series with natural language, AutoTimes leverages the token generation capabilities of LLMs to handle flexible series lengths and achieve competitive performance. The approach includes token-wise prompting to utilize timestamps for multimodal scenarios, inheriting zero-shot and in-context learning capabilities from LLMs. Empirical results show enhanced performance with larger LLMs and additional text or time series instructions.

title: Informer In Algorithmic Investment Strategies on High Frequency Bitcoin Data
abstract: The article investigates the usage of Informer architecture for building automated trading strategies for high frequency Bitcoin data. Three strategies using Informer model with different loss functions: Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE), Generalized Mean Absolute Directional Loss (GMADL) and Quantile loss, are proposed and evaluated against the Buy and Hold benchmark and two benchmark strategies based on technical indicators. The evaluation is conducted using data of various frequencies: 5 minute, 15 minute, and 30 minute intervals, over the 6 different periods. Although the Informer-based model with Quantile loss did not outperform the benchmark, two other models achieved better results. The performance of the model using RMSE loss worsens when used with higher frequency data while the model that uses novel GMADL loss function is benefiting from higher frequency data and when trained on 5 minute interval it beat all the other strategies on most of the testing periods.

title: LOB-Bench: Benchmarking Generative AI for Finance â an Application to Limit Order Book Data
abstract: Financial data presents a challenging sequence modeling task due to high noise, heavy tails, and strategic interactions, but progress has been hindered by the lack of consensus on quantitative evaluation paradigms. To address this, we present LOB-Bench, a Python-based benchmark designed to evaluate the quality and realism of generative message-by-order data for limit order books (LOB) in the LOBSTER format. The framework measures distributional differences in conditional and unconditional statistics between generated and real LOB data, supporting flexible multivariate statistical evaluation. It includes commonly used LOB statistics such as spread, order book volumes, order imbalance, and message inter-arrival times, along with discriminator network scores. Additionally, LOB-Bench incorporates market impact metrics like cross-correlations and price response functions. The benchmark evaluates autoregressive state-space models, (C)GAN, and parametric LOB models, finding that autoregressive GenAI outperforms traditional approaches.

title: Dimensionality reduction techniques to support insider trading detection
abstract: This paper proposes an unsupervised machine learning method for detecting potential insider trading activities by analyzing large and complex datasets. The method employs principal component analysis and autoencoders as dimensionality reduction techniques to identify contextual anomalies in trading positions around price-sensitive events. Reconstruction errors are used to flag suspicious investor behavior, with the approach applied to Italian stock data around takeover bids as a case study.

title: Quant5.0: Building AGI for Quantitative Investment
abstract: Traditional quantitative investment research faces diminishing returns and rising costs. To address these challenges, the authors introduce the Large Investment Model (LIM), a novel paradigm leveraging end-to-end learning and universal modeling. title: Mamba Meets Financial Markets: A Graph-Mamba Approach for Stock Price Prediction
abstract: Stock markets play a crucial role in the global economy, where accurate stock price predictions can yield significant financial returns. While transformer-based models have outperformed traditional LSTM and CNN models in financial time series prediction, their high computational complexity limits their practicality for real-time trading. This paper introduces SAMBA, an innovative framework that combines the Mamba architecture with graph neural networks (GNNs) for stock return prediction. SAMBA achieves near-linear computational complexity by using a bidirectional Mamba block to capture long-term dependencies in historical price data and adaptive graph convolution to model dependencies between daily stock features. title: Deep Learning for VWAP Execution in Crypto Markets: Beyond the Volume Curve
abstract: Volume-Weighted Average Price (VWAP) is a prevalent benchmark for trade execution, but achieving it is challenging due to dynamic volumes and prices. Traditional methods focus on forecasting the volume curve, which is suboptimal in volatile markets like cryptocurrency. This study proposes a deep learning framework that directly optimizes VWAP execution by bypassing volume curve prediction. Using automatic differentiation and custom loss functions, the method calibrates order allocation to minimize VWAP slippage. Results show this approach consistently outperforms conventional methods, even with a naive linear model, highlighting the advantage of directly modeling the execution objective. The framework is efficient and robust for volatile markets, with principles applicable to other asset classes.

This paper proposes a unified approach using hierarchical reinforcement learning (HRL) to jointly optimize both sub-tasks. A high-level policy selects asset pairs, while a low-level policy executes trading actions. This framework addresses the overfitting and target irrelevance issues in existing methods by dynamically learning from data and leveraging full historical information. title: DiffsFormer: A Diffusion Transformer on Stock Factor Augmentation
abstract: Machine learning models have shown significant promise in stock forecasting, but data scarcity, low signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), and data homogeneity hinder their performance. DiffsFormer is trained on a large-scale source domain to capture global joint distributions and then applied to downstream tasks by editing existing samples with controlled deviation. Experiments on CSI300 and CSI800 datasets demonstrate improvements of 7.2% and 27.8% in annualized return ratios, respectively. abstract: The stock market presents a challenging environment for accurately predicting future stock prices due to its intricate and ever-changing nature. Hidden Markov Models (HMMs) are statistical models that can model the behavior of a partially observable system, making them suitable for stock price prediction based on historical data. This paper trains and tests an HMM to predict stock closing prices using opening prices and preceding day's prices. The model's performance is evaluated using Mean Average Prediction Error (MAPE) and Directional Prediction Accuracy (DPA), a new indicator for correct sign predictions. title: MANA-Net: Mitigating Aggregated Sentiment Homogenization with News Weighting for Enhanced Market Prediction
abstract: Existing methods for financial sentiment analysis often rely on equal-weight and static aggregation of sentiments from multiple news items, leading to 'Aggregated Sentiment Homogenization'. This phenomenon causes sentiment representations to converge towards mean values, losing unique predictive information. To address this, we propose the Market Attention-weighted News Aggregation Network (MANA-Net), which dynamically weights news sentiments based on their relevance to market price changes. MANA-Net integrates news aggregation and market prediction into a unified model, optimizing sentiment representations for prediction. Evaluated on S&P 500 and NASDAQ 100 indices with financial news from 2003-2018, MANA-Net outperforms existing methods, improving Profit & Loss by 1.1% and the daily Sharpe ratio by 0.252.

abstract: This paper extends the tactical asset allocation literature by incorporating regime modeling using machine learning techniques. The authors propose a novel model that classifies current macroeconomic regimes, forecasts future regime distributions, and integrates these forecasts with historical asset performance to optimize portfolio allocations. Using the FRED-MD macroeconomic dataset, their approach employs a modified k-means algorithm for consistent regime classification over time. The regime predictions are then used to estimate expected returns and volatilities, which inform portfolio allocation strategies. The method outperforms traditional benchmarks like equal-weight, buy-and-hold, and random regime models, demonstrating significant improvements in portfolio performance. title: LEARNING TO EMBED TIME SERIES PATCHES INDEPENDENTLY
abstract: Masked time series modeling has gained attention as a self-supervised representation learning strategy. Recent approaches patchify and mask time series, training Transformers to predict masked patches from unmasked ones. However, this paper argues that learning patch dependencies may not be optimal for time series representation. Instead, the authors propose embedding patches independently using a simple patch reconstruction task and a patch-wise MLP. Additionally, complementary contrastive learning is introduced to efficiently capture adjacent time series information. The proposed method, PITS, outperforms state-of-the-art Transformer-based models in forecasting and classification tasks while being more parameter- and time-efficient.

abstract: Real-world time series often contain intertwined multiple frequency components, making accurate forecasting challenging. This paper introduces TimeKAN, a KAN-based Frequency Decomposition Learning architecture, to address this issue. TimeKAN decomposes mixed frequency components into single frequency bands using Cascaded Frequency Decomposition (CFD) blocks, learns specific temporal patterns within each band via Multi-order KAN Representation Learning (M-KAN) blocks, and recombines them using Frequency Mixing blocks. The architecture leverages the flexibility of Kolmogorov-Arnold Networks (KAN) to model varying information densities across frequencies. Extensive experiments show that TimeKAN achieves state-of-the-art performance in long-term time series forecasting while being computationally lightweight.

abstract: This paper introduces StockMixer, a novel MLP-based architecture designed for stock price forecasting. abstract: Multi-step stock price prediction is essential for forecasting volatility and managing financial risks, yet it is challenging due to the highly stochastic nature of stock data. abstract: Investment managers connected to plan sponsors are more likely to be hired than non-connected managers, with the selection effect comparable to prior performance. Using data from 269 publicly traded companies (2019-2023), the study evaluates two prediction tasks: Annual Stock Price Difference (ASPD) and Difference between Current Stock Price and Intrinsic Value (DCSPIV). Results show LR outperforms CNN and LSTM, achieving 74.66% accuracy for ASPD and 72.85% for DCSPIV. The study highlights the potential of fundamental analysis in long-term stock prediction, offering insights for academic research and investment strategies.

title: QuantFactor REINFORCE: Mining Steady Formulaic Alpha Factors with Variance-bounded REINFORCE
abstract: The paper introduces QuantFactor REINFORCE (QFR), a novel reinforcement learning method for mining interpretable formulaic alpha factors in financial markets. Unlike existing deep learning approaches that lack interpretability, QFR leverages the REINFORCE algorithm to explore the complex search space of formulaic factors. The method addresses the limitations of Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) by utilizing a deterministic state transition function and introducing a dedicated baseline to reduce variance. Additionally, the information ratio is incorporated for reward shaping to enhance factor stability. Experimental results demonstrate that QFR improves correlation with asset returns by 3.83% and outperforms state-of-the-art methods in generating excess returns.

title: RETHINKING CHANNEL DEPENDENCE FOR MULTI-VARIATE TIME SERIES FORECASTING: LEARNING FROM LEADING INDICATORS
abstract: Recent advances in multivariate time series (MTS) forecasting have favored channel-independent methods, which avoid overfitting but ignore potential channel dependencies. This paper argues that locally stationary lead-lag relationships between variatesâwhere some lagged variates follow leading indicatorsâcan be leveraged for more accurate predictions. The authors propose LIFT, a method that dynamically estimates leading indicators and their leading steps, then uses this information to refine forecasts. LIFT acts as a plug-in compatible with any time series forecasting method. Experiments on six real-world datasets show that LIFT improves state-of-the-art methods by an average of 5.5%. The approach includes an efficient cross-correlation computation algorithm and a Lead-aware Refiner that adaptively filters frequency components of leading indicators.

title: FinRobot: An Open-Source AI Agent Platform for Financial Applications using Large Language Models
abstract: FinRobot is an open-source AI agent platform designed to bridge the gap between the finance sector and the AI community by leveraging Large Language Models (LLMs). The platform supports multiple financially specialized AI agents, structured into four layers: Financial AI Agents for formulating Financial Chain-of-Thought (CoT), Financial LLM Algorithms for dynamic model configuration, LLMOps and DataOps for model training and data handling, and Multi-source LLM Foundation Models for integrating diverse LLMs. FinRobot aims to democratize access to advanced financial analysis tools, enhancing transparency, scalability, and adaptability to global markets. The platform is open-sourced to foster collaboration and innovation in financial AI applications.

title: LOB-Based Deep Learning Models for Stock Price Trend Prediction: A Benchmark Study
abstract: This paper examines the robustness and generalizability of fifteen state-of-the-art Deep Learning (DL) models for Stock Price Trend Prediction (SPTP) using Limit Order Book (LOB) data. The authors introduce LOBCAST, an open-source framework for data preprocessing, model training, evaluation, and profit analysis. Experimental results show that while these models perform well on familiar datasets, their performance significantly drops on new data, questioning their real-world applicability. The study serves as a benchmark, highlighting both the potential and limitations of current DL approaches in financial markets.

title: Statistical Arbitrage in Rank Space
abstract: This paper explores the superior performance of statistical arbitrage in rank space, where stocks are indexed by their capitalization ranks rather than company names. The study demonstrates that rank space offers a more robust market representation and enhanced mean-reverting properties of residual returns. The proposed statistical arbitrage algorithm includes an intraday rebalancing mechanism for converting portfolios between name and rank space. Empirical results show that portfolios constructed in rank space using neural networks significantly outperform those in name space, achieving an average annual return of 35.68% and a Sharpe ratio of 3.28 from 2007 to 2022.

title: Online Learning of Order Flow and Market Impact with Bayesian Change-Point Detection Methods
abstract: This paper introduces Bayesian online change-point detection (BOCPD) methods to identify regime shifts in financial order flow in real-time, enabling online predictions of order flow and market impact. The authors propose a novel BOCPD method using a score-driven approach to accommodate temporal correlations and time-varying parameters within each regime. Empirical application to NASDAQ data demonstrates the model's superior out-of-sample predictive performance, correct specification, and accurate online predictions of order flow and market impact. The findings reveal concave relationships between price dynamics and time/volume within regimes, resembling characteristics of large orders. The model's ability to incorporate regime information enhances prediction accuracy compared to non-regime models.

title: PGN: The RNNâs New Successor is Effective for Long-Range Time Series Forecasting
abstract: This paper introduces the Parallel Gated Network (PGN) as a novel successor to RNNs, addressing their limitations in capturing long-term dependencies and inefficiencies in sequential execution. PGN employs a Historical Information Extraction (HIE) layer and gated mechanisms to reduce information propagation paths to O(1). To enhance performance in long-range time series forecasting, the authors propose Temporal PGN (TPGN), a framework with two branches: one using PGN for long-term periodic patterns and another using patches for short-term information. TPGN achieves a theoretical complexity of O(âL) and demonstrates state-of-the-art performance on five benchmark datasets.

title: Time series momentum
abstract: This paper documents significant 'time series momentum' in equity index, currency, commodity, and bond futures across 58 liquid instruments. The study finds persistence in returns for one to 12 months, which partially reverses over longer horizons, aligning with sentiment theories of initial under-reaction and delayed over-reaction. A diversified portfolio of time series momentum strategies yields substantial abnormal returns with minimal exposure to standard asset pricing factors, performing best during extreme markets. The analysis reveals that speculators profit from time series momentum at the expense of hedgers, as evidenced by their trading activities.

title: Automate Strategy Finding with LLM in Quant investment
abstract: This paper proposes a novel framework for quantitative stock investment by leveraging Large Language Models (LLMs) and multi-agent architectures. The framework addresses instability and uncertainty in existing deep learning models by integrating LLMs to generate diversified alphas and employing a multi-agent approach for dynamic market evaluation. The first module extracts predictive signals from multimodal financial data, while the second module uses ensemble learning to create diverse trading agents. The third module dynamically selects and weights agents based on real-time market conditions. Extensive experiments on Chinese stock markets demonstrate superior performance over state-of-the-art baselines, highlighting the efficacy of combining LLM-generated alphas with multi-agent architectures for enhanced trading stability and performance.

title: Unified Training of Universal Time Series Forecasting Transformers
abstract: The paper introduces MOIRAI, a Masked EncOder-based UnIveRsAl TIme Series Forecasting Transformer, designed to address the challenges of universal time series forecasting. Traditional deep learning approaches for time series forecasting are limited by the one-model-per-dataset framework, which fails to leverage the benefits of large pre-trained models. MOIRAI overcomes key challenges such as cross-frequency learning, handling arbitrary numbers of variates in multivariate time series, and addressing varying distributional properties in large-scale data. The model is trained on the Large-scale Open Time Series Archive (LOTSA), featuring over 27B observations across nine domains. MOIRAI demonstrates competitive or superior performance as a zero-shot forecaster compared to full-shot models, showcasing its potential to revolutionize time series forecasting.

title: Machine learning in the Chinese stock market
abstract: This study contributes to the literature on empirical asset pricing in the Chinese stock market by utilizing various machine learning algorithms to analyze a comprehensive set of return prediction factors. Unlike findings from the US market, liquidity emerges as the most significant predictor, prompting an examination of transaction costs' impact. The dominance of retail investors enhances short-term predictability, especially for small stocks. Additionally, large stocks and state-owned enterprises exhibit high predictability over longer horizons. The out-of-sample performance remains economically significant even after accounting for transaction costs.

title: From Man vs. Machine to Man + Machine: The Art and AI of Stock Analyses
abstract: An AI analyst trained to digest corporate disclosures, industry trends, and macroeconomic indicators surpasses most analysts in stock return predictions. Nevertheless, humans win 'Man vs. Machine' when institutional knowledge is crucial, e.g., involving intangible assets and financial distress. AI wins when information is transparent but voluminous. Humans provide significant incremental value in 'Man + Machine,' which also substantially reduces extreme errors. Analysts catch up with machines after 'alternative data' become available if their employers build AI capabilities. Documented synergies between humans and machines inform how humans can leverage their advantage for better adaptation to the growing AI prowess.

title: Deep Reinforcement Learning for Cryptocurrency Trading: Practical Approach to Address Backtest Overfitting
abstract: Designing profitable and reliable trading strategies in the highly volatile cryptocurrency market is challenging. Existing deep reinforcement learning (DRL) methods often report increased profits in backtesting but may suffer from false positives due to model overfitting. This paper proposes a practical approach to address backtest overfitting for cryptocurrency trading using DRL. The method formulates overfitting detection as a hypothesis test, trains DRL agents, estimates overfitting probability, and rejects overfitted agents to improve trading performance. Testing on 10 cryptocurrencies during a period with two market crashes (05/01/2022 to 06/27/2022) shows that less overfitted DRL agents achieve higher returns than overfitted agents, an equal weight strategy, and the S&P DBM Index, suggesting potential real-market applicability.

title: DSPO: An End-to-End Framework for Direct Sorted Portfolio Construction
abstract: In quantitative investment, constructing characteristic-sorted portfolios is a crucial strategy for asset allocation. Traditional methods require extensive manual design and suffer from misalignment between prediction and optimization goals. To address these challenges, we introduce Direct Sorted Portfolio Optimization (DSPO), an innovative end-to-end framework that efficiently processes raw stock data to construct sorted portfolios directly. DSPO's neural network architecture seamlessly transitions stock data from input to output while modeling intra-dependency of time-steps and inter-dependency among all tradable stocks. Additionally, we incorporate a novel Monotonical Logistic Regression loss to maximize the likelihood of constructing optimal sorted portfolios. Empirical results demonstrate DSPO's effectiveness, yielding a RankIC of 10.12% and an accumulated return of 121.94% on the New York Stock Exchange in 2023-2024.

title: JAX-LOB: A GPU-Accelerated limit order book simulator to unlock large scale reinforcement learning for trading
abstract: Financial exchanges use limit order books (LOBs) to process orders and match trades. Efficient large-scale LOB simulators are crucial for research, particularly in agent-based models, reinforcement learning (RL), and generative models. This paper introduces JAX-LOB, the first GPU-accelerated LOB simulator designed to process thousands of books in parallel with reduced per-message processing time. The simulator leverages JAX to optimize performance without compromising realism. The paper also demonstrates an integration with JAX packages for solving optimal execution problems using RL, showcasing a 7x speedup in training compared to CPU-based simulators. The implementation is open-sourced to facilitate further research.

title: Fast ES-RNN: A GPU Implementation of the ES-RNN Algorithm
abstract: Time series forecasting is crucial across various domains, and the ES-RNN algorithm, a hybrid of classical state space models and modern RNNs, achieved a 9.4% sMAPE improvement in the M4 competition. This paper presents a GPU-accelerated implementation of ES-RNN, which vectorizes the original algorithm and leverages PyTorch for GPU computation. The new implementation achieves up to 322x training speedup while maintaining similar accuracy. The code is made accessible to the forecasting and machine learning community, facilitating broader adoption and generalization of hybrid models in time series forecasting.

title: XTab: Cross-table Pretraining for Tabular Transformers
abstract: The paper introduces XTab, a framework for cross-table pretraining of tabular transformers to address the challenge of inconsistent column types and quantities among tables. XTab utilizes independent featurizers and federated learning to pretrain shared components, enabling knowledge transfer across diverse tabular datasets. Evaluated on 84 tasks from the OpenML-AutoML Benchmark, XTab demonstrates improved generalizability, learning speed, and performance for tabular transformers. Notably, pretraining FT-Transformer with XTab achieves superior results in regression, binary, and multiclass classification tasks compared to state-of-the-art models.

title: Adaptive Long-Short Pattern Transformer for Stock Investment Selection
abstract: Stock investment selection is challenging due to non-stationary dynamics and complex market interdependencies. Existing methods, primarily based on RNNs, struggle with capturing interactive information among fine-grained volatility patterns and often treat stocks as isolated or rely on fixed graph structures. This paper introduces the Adaptive Long-Short Pattern Transformer (ALSP-TF) for stock ranking by expected returns. ALSP-TF enhances canonical self-attention with a fine-grained pattern distiller to contextualize queries and keys based on localized feature scales and a time-adaptive modulator to adjust dependency modeling across different time intervals. Additionally, a graph self-supervised regularization is devised to automatically assimilate stock synergies, improving model generalization. Experiments on three exchange market datasets demonstrate ALSP-TF's superiority over state-of-the-art stock forecast methods.

abstract: This paper provides detailed descriptions, including over 550 mathematical formulas, for over 150 trading strategies across various asset classes and trading styles. It covers stocks, options, fixed income, futures, ETFs, indexes, commodities, foreign exchange, convertibles, structured assets, volatility, real estate, distressed assets, cash, cryptocurrencies, and more. Some strategies incorporate machine learning algorithms like artificial neural networks, Bayes, and k-nearest neighbors. title: Learning to Generate Explainable Stock Predictions using Self-Reflective Large Language Models
abstract: This paper introduces the Summarize-Explain-Predict (SEP) framework, which leverages self-reflective Large Language Models (LLMs) to generate explainable stock predictions autonomously. Traditional deep learning models struggle with explainability, often limited to visualizing attention weights. SEP addresses this by using a verbal self-reflective agent and Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) to train LLMs to weigh the impact of chaotic social texts on stock prices and generate human-readable explanations. The framework eliminates the need for expert-annotated training samples by using self-generated responses during the reflective process. Experimental results show that the SEP framework outperforms traditional deep-learning and LLM methods in prediction accuracy and Matthews correlation coefficient for stock classification tasks, and demonstrates effectiveness in portfolio construction.

title: LESS IS MORE: AI DECISION-MAKING USING DYNAMIC DEEP NEURAL NETWORKS FOR SHORT-TERM STOCK INDEX PREDICTION
abstract: This paper introduces a multi-agent deep-learning method, Model A, for trading in the US S&P 500 Futures markets. Model A innovates on existing machine-learning models by sampling market prices and derivatives to make daily long/short/close decisions. Compared to conventional methods like Long Short-Term Memory, Random Forest, and Gradient-Boosted-Trees, Model A outperforms passive investments and these comparators over a six-year period (2018-23). It achieves top-quartile performance among US Large Cap active fund managers with only 41.95% market exposure, offering higher profitability and lower risk. Key metrics include an annualized return of 14.92% and a Sharpe ratio of 1.16.

title: Trend following with momentum versus moving averages: a tale of differences
abstract: This paper compares and contrasts the two most popular trend-following rules, momentum (MOM) and moving average (MA) rules, from a theoretical perspective. The study provides theoretical results on the similarity between different trend-following rules and their forecast accuracy. Findings indicate high similarity between MOM and MA rules, which increases with trend strength, but MA rules exhibit more robust forecast accuracy for future price trends. The paper also introduces a hypothesis about uncertain market dynamics, explaining why MA rules outperform MOM rules empirically. The theoretical results are supported by numerical illustrations and real-world examples, offering practical implications for trend-following strategies.

title: Attention-Based Reading, Highlighting, and Forecasting of the Limit Order Book
abstract: Managing high-frequency data in a limit order book (LOB) is complex, often beyond the capabilities of conventional time-series models. This study introduces advanced sequence-to-sequence models to forecast the entire multi-level LOB, including prices and volumes. The key contribution is a compound multivariate embedding method that captures spatiotemporal relationships. Empirical results show that the method outperforms others, achieving the lowest forecasting error while maintaining LOB structure. The approach integrates both price and volume information, enhancing predictive accuracy compared to traditional models.

title: Enhancing Stock Movement Prediction with Adversarial Training
abstract: This paper introduces a novel machine learning approach for stock movement prediction, focusing on predicting whether a stock's price will rise or fall in the near future. The key innovation is the use of adversarial training to enhance the generalization of a neural network prediction model. Given that stock price features are inherently stochastic and time-varying, traditional static feature-based training methods often lead to overfitting. The proposed method addresses this by simulating price stochasticity through intentional perturbations during training, ensuring the model performs well under such variations. Experimental results on real-world stock datasets demonstrate a 3.11% average accuracy improvement over state-of-the-art methods, validating the effectiveness of adversarial training in stock prediction.

title: Large Language Models for Financial Aid in Financial Time-series Forecasting
abstract: Financial time series forecasting in financial aid presents unique challenges due to limited historical datasets and high-dimensional financial information. This paper explores the use of pre-trained foundation models, including large language models (LLMs) like GPT-2, transformers, and linear models, to address these challenges. The study benchmarks these models against traditional approaches, demonstrating their superior performance in few-shot and zero-shot learning scenarios. The research includes a comprehensive evaluation across eight datasets from four financial domains, highlighting the potential of LLMs for scarce financial datasets. The findings contribute to the advancement of predictive models in financial aid and time series forecasting, with open-source code and datasets provided for reproducibility.
